user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarGetInfo(osal_id_t var_id, OS_condvar_prop_t *condvar_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    int32               return_code;
    OS_object_token_t   token;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(condvar_prop);

    memset(condvar_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_condvar_prop_t));

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR, var_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_condvar_table, token);

        strncpy(condvar_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(condvar_prop->name) - 1);
        condvar_prop->creator = record->creator;

        return_code = OS_CondVarGetInfo_Impl(&token, condvar_prop);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CondVarGetInfo:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_condvar_table
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char      name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t creator;
} OS_condvar_prop_t
...
int32 OS_CondVarGetInfo_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_condvar_prop_t *condvar_prop)
{
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR 0x0D
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I did not mark the remaining fragments (variable declarations, the final return statement, macro/constant definitions, the OS_ObjectIdGetById implementation, the simple OS_CondVarGetInfo_Impl stub, and the OS_ObjectIdRelease call definition) as suspicious for unreachable code because they are either simple declarations, obvious control-flow returns, or small utility routines whose bodies are explicit and do not contain code that is syntactically impossible to reach (e.g. no code after an unconditional return inside the same function). The selected fragments are the places where control-flow depends on external macros or functions (BUGCHECK/OS_CHECK_POINTER and OS_ObjectIdGetById) or where work is performed only under a success branch; these are the spots most likely to conceal unreachable code due to the behavior of the macros/functions involved and so should be investigated further.
